StateName wrong detection
items.body:
Hello. I tested usaddress locally. I found some interesting test cases.
For example:
This is my generated test case:
Front Street North 695 Gilbert Z1 35904

Output:
('Front', 'StreetName'),
 ('Street', 'StreetNamePostType'),
 ('North', 'StreetNamePostDirectional'),
 ('695', 'OccupancyIdentifier'),
 ('Gilbert', 'PlaceName'),
 ('Z1', 'StateName'),
 ('35904', 'ZipCode')

Expected output:
('Front', 'StreetName'),
 ('Street', 'StreetNamePostType'),
 ('North', 'StreetNamePostDirectional'),
 ('695', 'OccupancyIdentifier'),
 ('Gilbert', 'PlaceName'),
 ('Z1', ' anything but not State '), 
 ('35904', ' zipcode or anything else')

Example with real world data:
Italian address, exactly Sardinia
CMR 467 Box 7000 APO, AE 09096

Output:
('CMR', 'USPSBoxType'),
 ('467', 'USPSBoxID'),
 ('Box', 'USPSBoxType'),
 ('7000', 'USPSBoxID'),
 ('APO,', 'PlaceName'),
 ('AE', 'StateName'),
 ('09096', 'ZipCode')

May be by format this address is relevant, but this is not US addresses. 

To solve that problem I generated many test cases where it would fail, Should I after-train the model ?

items.body:
I am working at adding additional STREET_NAMES in the `usaddress/__init__.py`.  One of the STREET_NAMES I added was 'crt'.  Unfortunately, this caused one of the unit tests to fail.  

This is an unusual address, for certain, but I *think* it should be tagged such that "187th Street" is the street name, and StreetNamePostType is 'crt'. items.title: Some Windows test builds are failing to install lxml
items.body:
Appveyor has been angry about lxml every since we [bumped the requirement from 3.6.0 to 3.7.3 in parserator](https://github.com/datamade/parserator/commit/0963dd444fd665fa4b93c16a9932892a0ff198a7) and seems to be unable to install it. We're getting variations of [this error message] (https://ci.appveyor.com/project/fgregg/usaddress/build/1.0.50/job/ovarsc9aqjsgxbfw#L129) in builds for Python 3.4: 

```
C:\Users\appveyor\AppData\Local\Temp\1\xmlXPathInitk413vky1.c(1) : fatal error C1083: Cannot open include file: 'libxml/xpath.h': No such file or directory
    *********************************************************************************
    Could not find function xmlCheckVersion in library libxml2. Is libxml2 installed?
    *********************************************************************************
```

The error seems to happen when Appveyor has to build lxml from source ([sample here, Python 3.4 on x64](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/fgregg/usaddress/build/1.0.50/job/a5a1f3atkm1iodt4)). When it builds a wheel instead ([as it does for Python 2.7](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/fgregg/usaddress/build/1.0.50/job/26c1crepo77ld6fk#L27)) everything runs smoothly. Seems like there are no wheels for Python 3.4 and Windows architectures [on PyPi.](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/lxml/3.7.3)

items.title: Transform the abbreviations of street name post type?
items.body:
`>>>addr='123 Main St. Suite 100 Chicago, IL'`
`>>> usaddress.parse(addr)`
`(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', u'123'), ('StreetName', u'Main'), ('StreetNamePostType', u'St.'), ('OccupancyType', u'Suite'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', u'100'), ('PlaceName', u'Chicago'), ('StateName', u'IL')]), 'Street Address')`

It would be nice if we can transform the abbreviation of street name post type (or more fields), by passing another parameter to usaddress, as in:
`>>> usaddress.parse(addr, abbr=False)`
`(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', u'123'), ('StreetName', u'Main'), ('StreetNamePostType', u'Street'), ('OccupancyType', u'Suite'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', u'100'), ('PlaceName', u'Chicago'), ('StateName', u'IL')]), 'Street Address')`

This can be very useful for people like me who are dealing with a lot of address comparisons.

items.title: RepeatedLabelError when street name contains a number
items.body:
Hi there, thanks for providing this module, it's super useful! I'm trying to use it to parse addresses that in a dataset that came from our county's Voter Registration office, but I'm having problems with some of the addresses. Specifically, some of the addresses have a street name that contains a number, because the street name is just 'STATE ROUTE NNN', for example:
```python

>>> usaddress.tag('261  STATE ROUTE 590  ELMHURST TWP, PA  18444')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/luser/.pyenv/versions/2.7.11/lib/python2.7/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 178, in tag
    label)
usaddress.RepeatedLabelError: 
ERROR: Unable to tag this string because more than one area of the string has the same label

ORIGINAL STRING:  261  STATE ROUTE 590  ELMHURST TWP, PA  18444
PARSED TOKENS:    [(u'261', 'AddressNumber'), (u'STATE', 'StreetNamePreType'), (u'ROUTE', 'StreetNamePreType'), (u'590', 'AddressNumber'), (u'ELMHURST', 'StreetName'), (u'TWP,', 'PlaceName'), (u'PA', 'StateName'), (u'18444', 'ZipCode')]
UNCERTAIN LABEL:  AddressNumber

When this error is raised, it's likely that either (1) the string is not a valid person/corporation name or (2) some tokens were labeled incorrectly

To report an error in labeling a valid name, open an issue at https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/issues/new - it'll help us continue to improve probablepeople!

For more information, see the documentation at https://usaddress.readthedocs.io/
```

Here's the full list of addresses that hit this error from the dataset: [addresses.txt](https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/files/767145/addresses.txt)

items.title: Tool to merge tagged data back down to simple address fields
items.body:
In our DB we have the fields:

 - name
 - address1
 - address2
 - city
 - state
 - zip

And we're using this library to convert between a string address with newlines into those fields. It seems though, like this is a pretty complicated thing to figure out:

 - Handling of PO Boxes?
 - Handling of Street Addresses?
 - Which fields are address1 and which are address2?
 - Etc.

It'd be great if this library had a function to merge the output from `tag` into the kinds of fields that might be in a database like ours.

items.title: Verify training data in f731af
items.body:
I added training data from `unparseable.csv` before I had a solid understanding of the existing training data and the URISA standard. I'm wondering if this is contributing to depreciating performance in #153 and #155.

I'm going to look through the new training data in [f731af](https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/commit/f731afdb58f32c47c0fea9ba2f79ebea4c26ad63) and verify that it 1) meets the URISA standard and 2) does not include excessive examples of unusual address patterns.

items.title: Rearrange order of `LABELS` in __init__.py
items.body: It would make it a little easier to do manual tagging if the fields in the `LABELS` list are sort of in the positions they normally would be in an address.

items.title: Subaddress parsing (Address Ranges)
items.body:
I'm working with a dataset that contains a lot of address ranges.  I did a quick scan of the issues and didn't see anyone discussing these kinds of addresses.

For example:
````
>>> usaddress.tag('4120-4140 Annapolis Rd, Baltimore, MD 21227')
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', u'4120-4140'), ('StreetName', u'Annapolis'), ('StreetNamePostType', u'Rd'), ('PlaceName', u'Baltimore'), ('StateName', u'MD'), ('ZipCode', u'21227')]), 'Street Address')
````

In this case, per the URISA documentation, I might expect the Address Number to be some type of Subaddress, given one of their definitions of a "Complete Subaddress" is "Two Complete Address Numbers, separated by a hyphen, and followed by a Complete Street Name (in the case of a Two Number Address Range)".

Right now, I'm leaning towards usaddress' current behavior being the most correct and that I should handle the distinction myself, but I wanted to open the discussion.

items.title: Best practice for fixing failed tests?
items.body:
In the latest build, five tests failed. Two of these have been failing for a while, and are due to unusual spellings:

```python
# Changing "Hgwy" -> "Hwy" fixes the failure
ADDRESS:     b'12631 Imperial Hgwy Santa Fe CA 90670'
pred:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode')
true:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode')
```

```python
# Changing "Pakway" -> "Parkway" fixes the failure
ADDRESS:     b'1341 Northeast Orenco Station Pakway, Hillsboro, OR 97124'
pred:        ['AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode']
true:        ['AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode']
```

In one of the three new failures, it seems that the new training data has weighted the model in the wrong direction:

```python
ADDRESS:     b'Hwys 16 And 63 North, Spring Valley, MN 55975'
pred:        ['SubaddressType', 'SubaddressIdentifier', 'SubaddressType', 'SubaddressIdentifier', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode']
true:        ['StreetName', 'StreetName', 'IntersectionSeparator', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'PlaceName', 'PlaceName', 'StateName', 'ZipCode']
```

(The last batch of training data contained lots of examples of unusual subaddresses that appeared at the front of the string.)

These cases seem like __proper failures__. We should try to tweak the model so that it passes these tests.

In two of the new failures, however, the "true" output strikes me as debatable:

```python
# Floors can be either subaddresses or occupancy types, depending on the context)
ADDRESS:     b'431 Marietta St NW Floor 3'
pred:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'SubaddressIdentifier', 'SubaddressType', 'SubaddressIdentifier')
true:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'StreetNamePostDirectional', 'OccupancyType', 'OccupancyIdentifier')
```

```python
# Since 123456789 is not a valid zip code, both `OccupancyIdentifier` and `ZipCode` seem like reasonable guesses to me
ADDRESS:     b'123 W Hastings St 123456789'
pred:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetNamePreDirectional', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'OccupancyIdentifier')
true:        ('AddressNumber', 'StreetNamePreDirectional', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'ZipCode')
```

These cases seem like __improper failures__. We should tweak the tests to be less ambiguous.

Whether we're dealing with "proper" or "improper" failures, __what's our standard procedure for addressing failed tests?__ For failures that seem like true mistakes, my instinct is to hunt around for valid addresses that resemble the failure and add them to the training data. For failures where the parse succeeds but its output is debatably correct, my instinct is to remove the tests and add less ambiguous real-world examples that get at the meat of the test. 

If we have a policy, it might make sense to add it to the documentation in case someone creates a new build and needs to deal with failed tests.

items.title: Incorrect tag's assigned when person name and address string contains separator comma's
items.body:
Without comma we get the proper recipient tags and address tags:
usaddress.parse('JASON BOURNE 90 CLAIRE GULCH CLANCY MT 59634-9528 ')

However, it commas in different spots does not appear to work.
usaddress.parse('JASON BOURNE, 90 CLAIRE GULCH, CLANCY MT 59634-9528 ')
usaddress.parse('JASON, BOURNE, 90 CLAIRE GULCH, CLANCY MT 59634-9528 ')
usaddress.parse('JASON BOURNE, 90 CLAIRE GULCH, CLANCY, MT, 59634-9528')

However, adding c/o, ATT, ATTN, star, FOB etc infront of the above three will produce the correct result (as in the first case above). Example:
usaddress.parse('ATT JASON BOURNE, 90 CLAIRE GULCH, CLANCY, MT, 59634-9528')

items.title: Recipient tagged as Subaddress Type
items.body:
usaddress.parse('JANET S SMITH 7710 MAIN AVE APT 1110 LOS ANGELES CA 9151-2100 ')

Appears to be where the name could be a street name and the middle initial is directional (N, S, E, W).

Output looks like
JANET, SubaddressType
S, SubaddressIdentifier
SMITH, SubaddressType

Using usaddress.tag fails, since there are two SubaddressType seperated by SubaddressIdentifier. 

Perhaps if there is a sequence of SubaddressType > SubaddressIdentifier > SubaddressType > followed by valid address tags, to assign bigger weight towards that combo being a Recipient rather than Subaddress.

items.title: Add user-friendly documentation for address tagging
items.body:
The current documentation isn't very helpful for quickly understanding the US Thoroughfare, Landmark, and Postal Address Data Standard. We ask users to either read [the official docs](http://www.urisa.org/clientuploads/directory/GMI/Professional%20Practice/Address%20Standard/AddressStandard_Approved_Apr11_03Class.pdf) (which is long and known to induce headaches) or [see examples in our docs](http://usaddress.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#details) (which don't cover the most confusing edge cases, and also aren't very well advertised). To encourage users to tag their own training data, we should improve the information on our documentation page and make sure it's better advertised.

We should also add a short note about what to do if tests fail in the process of making a new build.

items.title: Suite Number not parsed
items.body:
When a suite, office, or apartment number is not labeled as such, it is not identified using usaddress.tag().

Example:
ORIGINAL STRING:  14855 Blanco Rd.  #108 None San Antonio TX 78216
PARSED TOKENS:    [(u'14855', 'AddressNumber'), (u'Blanco', 'StreetName'), (u'Rd.', 'StreetNamePostType'), (u'#', 'OccupancyIdentifier'), (u'108', 'AddressNumber'), (u'None', 'StreetName'), (u'San', 'PlaceName'), (u'Antonio', 'PlaceName'), (u'TX', 'StateName'), (u'78216', 'ZipCode')]
UNCERTAIN LABEL:  AddressNumber

When this error is raised, it's likely that either (1) the string is not a valid person/corporation name or (2) some tokens were labeled incorrectly

This will be parsed using usaddress.parse(), however the 'OccupancyIdentifier' will be found as '#'.

items.title: unabbreviated street types aren't labeled properly
items.body:
I've come across a parsing issue when the PlaceName and StreetName are the same, and there is a unit number at the end of the address string. While I can't post the actual address that I used, It is really easy to reproduce with a made up address.

```
>>> fails = '12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD #26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(fails)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 94, in tag
    raise RepeatedLabelError(address_string, parse(address_string), label)
usaddress.RepeatedLabelError:

ERROR: Unable to tag this string because more than one area of the string has the same label

ORIGINAL STRING:  12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD #26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789
PARSED TOKENS:    [('12345', 'AddressNumber'), ('CLEVELAND', 'StreetName'), ('BOULEVARD', 'StreetNamePreType'), ('#', 'StreetName'), ('26,', 'StreetName'), ('CLEVELAND', 'PlaceName'), ('OH', 'StateName'), ('12345-6789', 'ZipCode')]
UNCERTAIN LABEL:  StreetName

When this error is raised, it's likely that either (1) the string is not a valid address or (2) some tokens were labeled incorrectly

To report an error in labeling a valid address, open an issue at https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/issues/new - it'll help us continue to improve usaddress!

For more information, see the documentation at http://usaddress.readthedocs.org/
```

These variants also fail:

```
'12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD #26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789'
'12345 TAMPA BOULEVARD #26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789'
```

However, the following address parses, showing that the repeated city name may be a factor.

```
>>> good = '12345 RIVER BOULEVARD #26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetName', 'RIVER'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'BOULEVARD'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StateName', 'OH'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

Also, clearly separating the occupancy identifier with a comma also resolves the issue:

```
>>> good = '12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD,  # 26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'BOULEVARD'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StateName', 'OH'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

Using the more mundane 'ROAD' instead of 'BOULEVARD' makes things parse without an error, but the results are clearly incorrect, with the Occupancy identifier shown as the street name:

```
>>> not_really_good = '12345 TAMPA ROAD #26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(not_really_good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetNamePreType', 'TAMPA ROAD'), ('StreetName', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'TAMPA'), ('StateName', 'FL'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')

>>> not_really_good = '12345 TAMPA ROAD # 26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(not_really_good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetNamePreType', 'TAMPA ROAD'), ('StreetName', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'TAMPA'), ('StateName', 'FL'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')

>>> not_really_good = '12345 CLEVELAND ROAD #26, CLEVELAND OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(not_really_good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetNamePreType', 'CLEVELAND ROAD'), ('StreetName', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StateName', 'OH'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

Adding a comma between city and state also make it better:

```
>>> good = '12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD # 26, CLEVELAND, OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'BOULEVARD'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'CLEVELAND'), ('StateName', 'OH'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

Using the 'BLVD' abbreviation will fix the problem as well:

```
>>> good = '12345 TAMPA BLVD #26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetName', 'TAMPA'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'BLVD'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'TAMPA'), ('StateName', 'FL'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

The street name appears to have to be a likely to be a well known city name to trigger the problem, as this parses.

```
>>> good = '12345 RIVER BOULEVARD #26, RIVER OH 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(good)
(OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '12345'), ('StreetName', 'RIVER'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'BOULEVARD'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '# 26'), ('PlaceName', 'RIVER'), ('StateName', 'OH'), ('ZipCode', '12345-6789')]), 'Street Address')
```

EDIT: The fact that the street name is a common city name seems to be more important than the repetition:

```
>>> also_bad = '12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD # 26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789'
>>> usaddress.tag(also_bad)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 94, in tag
    raise RepeatedLabelError(address_string, parse(address_string), label)
usaddress.RepeatedLabelError:

ERROR: Unable to tag this string because more than one area of the string has the same label

ORIGINAL STRING:  12345 CLEVELAND BOULEVARD # 26, TAMPA FL 12345-6789
PARSED TOKENS:    [('12345', 'AddressNumber'), ('CLEVELAND', 'StreetName'), ('BOULEVARD', 'StreetNamePreType'), ('#', 'StreetName'), ('26,', 'StreetName'), ('TAMPA', 'PlaceName'), ('FL', 'StateName'), ('12345-6789', 'ZipCode')]
UNCERTAIN LABEL:  StreetName

When this error is raised, it's likely that either (1) the string is not a valid address or (2) some tokens were labeled incorrectly

To report an error in labeling a valid address, open an issue at https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/issues/new - it'll help us continue to improve usaddress!

For more information, see the documentation at http://usaddress.readthedocs.org/
```

items.title: Exporting to CSV after python parse
items.body:
First of all - Love this tremendously. Second, I've been trying to use the usaddress.py + csv.py + pandas to import from a csv, parse the rows, then export the rows back out into a csv. 

However, when I run the code listed below, it (1) doesn't parse the column headers correctly and (2) doesn't then parse the fields correctly. This approached was recommended to me [over on StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31798061/output-a-changing-ordereddict-to-csv), so please let me know if (1) This approach is silly and/or (2) I'm merely suffering from noob-itis as I am, in fact, terribly new to python.

```
import pandas as pd
import usaddress
from pandas import DataFrame

data = ['Robie House, 5757 South Woodlawn Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637',
    'State & Lake, Chicago']

tagged_addresses = [usaddress.parse(line) for line in data]

address_df = pd.DataFrame(tagged_addresses)

address_df.to_csv('moooutput.csv')
```

items.title: Unicode tokens cause IndexError
items.body:
When trying to tag an address that has unicode tokens (after tokenization) the resulting clean token in tokenFeatures is an empty string causing an IndexError.

```
>>> import usaddress
>>> usaddress.tag('1 å drive')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 84, in tag
    for token, label in parse(address_string) :
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 73, in parse
    features = tokens2features(tokens)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 168, in tokens2features
    token_features = tokenFeatures(token)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/usaddress/__init__.py", line 141, in tokenFeatures
    features = {'abbrev' : token_clean[-1] == u'.',
IndexError: string index out of range
```

The fix (I think) should be:

```
token_clean = re.sub(r'(^[\W]*)|([^.\w]*$)', u'', token)
```

to

```
 token_clean = re.sub(r'(^[\W]*)|([^.\w]*$)', u'', token, flags=re.UNICODE)
```

items.title: Addresses in Texas Like '# Country Road 212' should be parsed differently
items.body:
So I am attempting to parse the address: "1 COUNTRY ROAD 212"
Which is giving the following output: (note I am parsing the result it into JSON format) 

``` JSON
[{"AddressNumber": "1"}, {"StreetName": "COUNTRY"}, {"StreetNamePostType": "ROAD"}, {"OccupancyIdentifier": "212"}]
```

When in Texas it uses the `Country Road #` as a street name for the rural areas.
Output should be something like:

``` JSON
[{"AddressNumber": "1"}, {"StreetName": "COUNTRY ROAD 212"}]
```

I assume that something `Country Rd 212` should be parsed with the same idea as above.

This is kind of a corner case, but I thought I should post an issue report anyways :+1:

items.title: Various prison addresses cause usaddress.tag to bail
items.body:
I work with databases of addresses of prisons, and there are a number of them that trip up `usaddress.tag`.  Below are the problematic addresses (taken from http://www.dc.state.fl.us/orginfo/facilitydir.html, http://www.tdcj.state.tx.us/unit_directory/, and http://www.bop.gov/locations/list.jsp ).  If there's a more helpful way for me to report/package these failures let me know how.

A few trends:
- "Unit" is taken as `OcupancyType` even when it should sometimes be recipient.
- Weird Texas road names ("FM", "Spur", "Hwy")
- Including both PO Box and street address trips things up.
- Doubly-named streets (such as  700 NE 55th Blvd, State Road 26 East -- "State Road 26 East" is a redundant name of "NE 55th Blvd", but the address as given includes both).

It's an interesting question as to whether the last two (PO Box with street and doubly-named streets) are considered "valid" addresses.  The redundant street info is clearly not needed; but the address as rendered by official sources includes it.  Letters addressed that way would arrive.  So I'd suggest that even though it's weird and _maybe_ non-conformant, `usaddress` as a tool for handling in-the-wild addresses shouldn't bail out when it encounters them.

items.title: Feature Request: Address normalization
items.body:
Any plans in the near future to add address normalization function(s) as well?
example from a dataset I'm working with:
1909 North Hwy 81
1909 N Highway 81

These are identical addresses, and the idea would be to have a new function that would take the output of the parse function and normalize each address component value to canonical values, so that we can apply an equality function that would return True if the above example strings were parsed and normalized.

items.title: 'Null' tag?
items.body:
In usaddress 0.3.4:

``` python
import usaddress
usaddress.tag("728 W. Roosevelt Road (East Side) 2nd floor")
```

``` python
> (OrderedDict([('AddressNumber', '728'), ('StreetNamePreDirectional', 'W.'), ('StreetName', 'Roosevelt'), ('StreetNamePostType', 'Road'), ('Null', '(East Side)'), ('OccupancyIdentifier', '2nd'), ('OccupancyType', 'floor')]),
 'Street Address')
```

`Null` is a bit confusing to me. Is this a part of the address we can't identify? Could we call it something else?

items.title: crash on unicode vulgar fractions
items.body:
Some tokens that we can expect in Latin unicode address strings are entirely non-word, non-punctuation characters:

```
In [21]: addr = u'1711 N 6th ½ St #100'

In [22]: tokens = tokenize(addr)

In [23]: tokens
Out[23]: [u'1711', u'N', u'6th', u'\xbd', u'St', u'#', u'100']

In [24]: re.sub(r'(^[\W]*)|([^.\w]*$)', u'', tokens[3])  # token_clean
Out[24]: u''
```

This empty string for `token_clean` [results in an IndexError here](https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/blob/master/usaddress/__init__.py#L142):

```
134: UnicodeWarning: Unicode equal comparison failed to convert both arguments to Unicode - interpreting them as being unequal
  if token in (u'&', u'#') :
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
IndexError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
[...]
 in tokenFeatures(token)
    138     token_abbrev = re.sub(r'[.]', u'', token_clean.lower())
    139     features = {'nopunc' : token_abbrev,
--> 140                 'abbrev' : token_clean[-1] == u'.',
    141                 'case' : casing(token_clean),
    142                 'digits' : digits(token_clean),

IndexError: string index out of range
```

Would you consider adding vulgar fractions to the list of [single-character tokens](https://github.com/datamade/usaddress/blob/master/usaddress/__init__.py#L136), or passing the entire token through unidecode first? Let me know if a pull request would help.

items.title: Install error on Python 2.7.6 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS
items.body:
Install crashes badly on Ubuntu.  Some of the errors:

```
ERROR: /bin/sh: 1: xslt-config: not found
** make sure the development packages of libxml2 and libxslt are installed **
```

 ...
  Running setup.py install for parserator
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/parserator/utils.py", line 69
        def fit(self, X, y, **params, model_path):
                                    ^
    SyntaxError: invalid syntax

There are hundreds of GCC warnings as an attempt is made to build "crfsuite", which isn't good enough code for the high warning levels enabled.

After removing the existing installation of "lxml", PIP crashes trying to restore it:

Cleaning up...
Command /usr/bin/python -c "import setuptools, tokenize;**file**='/tmp/pip_build_root/lxml/setup.py';exec(compile(getattr(tokenize, 'open', open)(**file**).read().replace('\r\n', '\n'), **file**, 'exec'))" install --record /tmp/pip-MHzJKR-record/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip_build_root/lxml
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/pip", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('pip==1.5.4', 'console_scripts', 'pip')()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/**init**.py", line 185, in main
    return command.main(cmd_args)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 161, in main
    text = '\n'.join(complete_log)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 42: ordinal not in range(128)

The install may need the development library for libxslt, but it doesn't stop; it keeps plowing ahead and screwing up. It clearly wants one of the many lxml-related packages, but which one?

items.title: FL is being idententified as OccupancyType
items.body:
Many clean records with FL as state are not getting parsed.
I figured it was a version problem, and actually it was. Some of the FL records were parsed properly with 0.2.4. But, there still are some FL records that are not getting parsed. 

Example: TIMOTHY ADAMS HEADQU ORLANDO FL 328990001

The Web API (0.2.4, i guess) returns : "BuildingName","BuildingName","BuildingName","BuildingName","OccupancyType","OccupancyIdentifier"
"TIMOTHY","ADAMS","HEADQU","ORLANDO","FL","328990001" 

And 0.3.1 returns:

> > usaddress.parse("TIMOTHY ADAMS HEADQU ORLANDO FL 328990001")
> > [('TIMOTHY', 'BuildingName'), ('ADAMS', 'BuildingName'), ('HEADQU', 'BuildingName'),
> >  ('ORLANDO', 'BuildingName'), ('FL', 'OccupancyType'), ('328990001', 'OccupancyIdentifier')]

This is just one example. I get this problem only with some FL state records. All the other 49 states work fine for me.

items.title: API results different from local
items.body:
Thanks for a great tool. I'm puzzled, though -- results from the API look different from local results using the PyPI package or c2a0fe. Local results:

```
In [1]: import usaddress

In [2]: usaddress.parse('140 metro park suite a rochester ny 14623')
Out[2]: 
[('140', 'OccupancyIdentifier'),
 ('metro', 'BuildingName'),
 ('park', 'BuildingName'),
 ('suite', 'OccupancyType'),
 ('a', 'OccupancyIdentifier'),
 ('rochester', 'PlaceName'),
 ('ny', 'StateName'),
 ('14623', 'ZipCode')]
```

API results: 

```
{
    "input-address": "140 metro park suite a rochester ny 14623",
    "result": [
        {
            "value": "140",
            "tag": "AddressNumber"
        },
        {
            "value": "metro",

        },
        {

            "tag": "StateName"
        },
        {

            "tag": "ZipCode"
        }
    ]
}
```

From source, I trained locally using:

One test fails:

tional', 'StreetName', 'StreetName', 'StreetNamePostType', 'ZipCode'))

-------------------- >> begin captured stdout << ---------------------
ADDRESS:     550 West Van Buren Street, 60661

Results from source were the same as from PyPI. Results from the API look generally much better and I'd love to replicate them locally.
